text: I stopped one rainy night because the outside looked very interesting being an old firehouse in the strip. The inside didn't disappoint from the food and wine to the service. It has very relaxed and European feel to it. I look forward to my return.

Tuesday is the day to come to Bar Marco!

Although they have No Menu Mondays- where they bring in a different guest chef every Monday to cook a special dinner that usually benefits a charity- Tuesday's they have $5 specials on select appetizers (including their burger) and cocktails. This means you can come by and get a gourmet burger served with bacon and rosemary aioli and a hand crafted cocktail for $10, plus a hip atmosphere and sexy ambiance included for free. Cheers to that!

I visited Bar Marco recently on one of their 'No Menu Mondays'. It seemed like a fun idea & my friends & I wanted to try this place out (we had never been). We were extremely disappointed. For one thing, it was absolutely freezing downstairs. It was very cold outside that day & unfortunately it was also very cold on the inside. So cold that three of my friends wore their coats the entire time we were in there. It was awful. 

There was no menu so we asked the waiter what we were getting. The waiter had NO idea. He had not a clue what the chef was making that night. It took him 20 minutes to explain that there were four appetizers & two entrees to pick from while he tried to recall the ingredients. If the wait staff doesn't know what's going on, maybe you do need to have an actual menu?

Apparently Bar Marco doesn't have a drink menu. The waiter named four drinks, wasn't sure of the ingredients, but recommended two of them. I had a Dr. Cooper. It was delicious. However, there was less than two inches of actual drink in my glass & the cost, I found out later, was $12. Thank the lord I didn't order several. It was about $8 overpriced. 

For dinner I got a pasta dish with vegetables. It was good, but nothing special. It wasn't very large either. And it was $15. My friend then asked what was for dessert & we were told, "nothing". Great. 

The freezing cold air & the ridiculously overpriced drinks killed it for me. Add in the clueless water, the mediocre food & the complete lack of décor & I can't imagine I will come back here anytime soon.

FAVORITE restaurant in Pittsburgh. 

The staff is what makes BAR MARCO unique. Not just friendly and professional. They're exceptional. Always knowledgeable about the wine list and menu. Always interesting and interested. Even if the food was just very good, BAR MARCO would be the favorite...but, the food is EXCELLENT. 

Started with a fantastic dirty martini...capers instead of olives. Try the MEAN JOE...you'll be happy!  

Fresh hand made pastas, delicious salads...OMG, if asparagus is in season the white asparagus soup is a MUST.  The menu changes often, which is exciting.  Even though it is a small menu, there are ALWAYS three or four tantalizing choices. 

Don't pass up the desserts. 

The room is small and cozy. The service wonderful. 
Highly recommend.

Delicious brunch, appropriate portion sizes, and the BEST Bloody Mary I've ever had (and we're from Chicago and go to a lot of brunch places so I'm very picky about Bloody Marys).  We got there just after 10 and were able to get a table immediately but the line formed quickly behind us so you might want to get there early.

Never have I ever been disappointed with a cocktail that was made for me by these mixologists! Love the drinks!! If you know what you like, and can articulate those likes to the bartenders, they are sure to make you an awesome cocktail! Magical drink artists, I thank you! ;)!

The pros: Smart, clean atmosphere in a renovated firehouse. Excellent focaccia for a starter. Good drinks.

Cons: The service. Had it not been for the condescending server (and the atrocious dessert, sesame semifreddo, that resembled dried out halvah) Bar Marco would have received 3 stars. It began by the server telling our group of 4 that arrived at 6 PM that we had to be out by 7:30 b/c our table was reserved; the restaurant was half empty at 6 so we could have easily been seated at another table. (At 8 PM, when we walked back to our car after visiting the Strip District, Bar Marco had only a handful of customers. No one was at the table at which we had sat.) The server answered my question of "Do you serve small plates, tapas?" with "we HATE the term 'tapas.' the chef calls them medium plates." Chastised, my friends and I ordered 5 medium plates. After placing our order, the server said we should have ordered 2 plates per person, information that would have been helpful when I first inquired about plate size. 

As I don't eat meat, I asked if a sausage could be held or if it was already blended into the dish, a dish that I wouldn't have necessarily ordered but was put on the spot to order more food. No, every ingredient in the food was "essential." Traditionally, if a restaurant doesn't allow ingredients to be withheld or substituted, this is stated on the menu. Likewise, if a chef recommends ordering more than 1 plate per person or if the plate size differs from the norm, the customers are told this up front. Not a huge deal but the patronizing way that the information was conveyed was. (Also, as an FYI, 5 shared dishes would be enough food for 4 people. We didn't come close to finishing what we'd ordered.) 

Fast forward to 1 of the 3 dessert options, toffee pudding. Apparently it should have been labeled pear pudding b/d the server informed us that pear, the last ingredient listed, was, again, an "essential ingredient" prepared three ways so to withhold it would ruin the dessert. So, we had the $12 sesame semifreddo, which was so unappealing that each of us took just one sample bite and left the rest.  
 
As an aside, I grew around Pittsburgh and had always raved to my East Coast friends what a friendly, kind city it was. I visited Bar Marco with friends who had never been to the 'burgh and I was eager to show them how hip while nice Pittsburgh was. This was not the introduction that they received.

So far, I'd have to say Bar Marco is my top pick for grabbing some GOOD cocktails AND being able to also feed yourself with delicious food!

The main attraction at Bar Marco has got to be the cocktails.  They can make you anything.  You give them a few hints and characteristics of the types of cocktails you want and voila!  The bartender will craft a drink just for you.  My favorite so far has been a rye, vermouth, lavender, soda water drink that I got when I asked for something whiskey, but not syrupy, cinnamony or too heavy.

All the dishes at Bar Marco are on the smaller side, so again, the main attraction is the drinks.  But, a girl's got to eat and with those drinks, you should probably get a little into your stomach!  So don't expected to be stuffed to the brim, but definitely try some of their yummy dishes to go along with your drinks.  Between me and a girlfriend, we ordered 2 appetizer plates and an entree plate.  And it was the perfect amount!

The decor and atmosphere are also great at Bar Marco!  It's a small cozy space, so not ideal for groups, but perfect for dropping in with a friend or two.  Before the sun sets, the restaurant is flooded with light and has an airy lively vibe.  After the sun goes down, it gains a speakeasy electric feel.  My only complaint with the space is that it can get pretty loud in there with all the bare tiles.  But it adds to the lively ambiance.

And of course, service has always been very good.  Waiters and bartenders are all very patient as you piece together your wishes and desires for a drink!

I went to Bar Marco this past weekend with a few friends and boy did we find a gem in Pittsburgh.  This new spot has everything I look for in an ideal restaurant.  For starters it is extremely cozy, not in a cramped I can't get to the bar south-side sort of way, instead the owners welcome you to the bar, discuss wine/drink options and make you feel at home.  The food is OUTSTANDING!  I can't say in all my years of being a very serious carnivore have I been able to find a rib-eye so marvelously seasoned and beautifully cooked.  Not to mention, it was enormous.   As their menu rotates, I can only hope to catch another one in the near future.  The snacks were delicious too, my favorite being the sausage and polenta, with the meatballs as a close second.   This is one of those places you should go and enjoy slowly; a little bubbly, a yummy snack, followed by a good glass of wine and maybe an entree to share.  

The only downside was it was a little chilly, but then again it was January in Pittsburgh.  Simply said, come fully clothed and you will be fine.  

I hear there is a patio to come....... Could be the perfect summer's night spot!

Love this place! The food and drinks were delish. My friend got an old-fashioned and it was good. I told them I wanted something spicy for the cocktail and man, it was amazing! The cocktail had tequila, pineapple juice, muddled jalapeno, and other ingredients I don't remember. The food was simple, homey, and hearty. Love the atmosphere and service too. 

i'd say this place rival many restaurants in NYC.

Five stars for the drinks, three stars for the food, one star for the clientele

First, the worst part: there's a gross poseur factor. This is a place people to go to be able to say they went. "Oh, you've never been?" they'll sniff. If your tolerance for that sort of thing exceeds mine, it's a lovely venue. 

Second-worst: they play the music so loud that everyone has to yell. Everyone except for the staff, to whom you're perpetually saying "I'm sorry. I didn't catch that." If you're looking for a swank place to take a date to whom you don't want to talk, this is the restaurant for you.

Second-best part: The menu is very limited, and for me it's sometimes hard to find something that sounds appealing. It ranges from adequate to quite good. The bacon-wrapped dates are killer (they're hard to screw up), and I often just order two of those instead of an entree.  The portions are small.

Best part: You go here for the cocktails. Designer all. Yes, they're ootsy. They're also best in class. The finest Manhattan I've ever had, I had here. I can't remember the bartender's name, but he's an artist. He even conducts Manhattan-making classes.

We let the bartender design out drinks based on our preferences, and I had a delicious seasonal fall drink.  My meal was pretty good, but my boyfriend was not quiet as impressed.  The drinks were actually more memorable than the food.  I like the atmosphere--very in sync with the strip. I never made it to brunch, which I regret.  Fun place.

Around the corner from Leaf and Bean, Bar Marco delivers the best possible afterlife to one of Pittsburgh's old fire halls. This is how people built fire stations a century ago: tin ceilings, metal stairs, tile brick six feet up the wall.

Whoever renovated was kind to the kitchen staff--fully half the ground floor is devoted to food preparation, and the food can tell. I ordered lemon buttermilk pancakes with sweet cream, bacon and rhubarb compote. The pancakes were light and hot with crispy edges. I didn't even use the maple syrup until the last bite.

Michelle had her choice of five delicious savories and settled on an unusual, delicious burger with sweet bacon, sautéed red onion and an egg. Passed over: fried chicken with rhubarb-chili sauce, croque BLT on sourdough, baked eggs with pepperonata sauce, fried zucchini benedict.

In a 2012 Pittsburgh Magazine review, Valentina raved about their bar program, with bitters, tinctures, juices and syrups made from scratch. We didn't scratch the surface of their drink menu, but there was nothing wrong with the gently spicy Tito's Bloody Mary or the glowing mimosa.

Total bill under $60. (Elise told us they "do not accept any kind of gratuities.") Writing a food review on one's phone over a rainy Saturday morning brunch: priceless. 

(I paid with Discover.)

This snotty place is not worth your time.  However if you prefer being treated badly by pompous servers, go for it.

Our group were told by a man who much resembled Napoleon Dynamite that we were too loud.  I was stunned. The table of people nearest to us said we were completely fine.

I promise NEVER to go again and NEVER recommend to anyone, I won't be wasting my money here.

Bring back the Firehouse Lounge!

Superb cocktails and excellent food. 

Came alone on a business trip and sat at the bar. Not at all crowded at 8:30 on a Wednesday. 

Gave the bartender some vague guidance but mostly let him do what he wanted, which turned out great. 

Menu changes frequently but for what it's worth, the pig head croquettes were exceptional, the kale and faro salad was very good, and the rigatoni bolognese was "merely" good. 

My only complaint is that the rigatoni fell victim to the trend of serving pasta too al dente to the point of just being kind of chewy. But the sauce was on point with deep but subtle flavor and nice fall spices, which were complimented by a bourbon drink featuring similar spice notes.

We ate there on Feb. 6, 2016. Everything was fabulous - food, service, and drinks. Highly recommend the osso buco, it was really great. If you think the prices look high, please consider that there is no tipping -- we actually felt guilty about not tipping since we were so impressed with the quality and with the service. We had the beets, pork belly and brussel sprouts apps and they were all delicious.

Questions to ask yourself before going to Bar Marco...

1. Am I a hipster?
2. Do I love being crammed into a too small space with hipsters?
3. Do I like a place so pretentious that they don't have a cocktails menu but instead interview you on the flavors you like, come up with some concoction, then charge you $12 for a drink (a fact they don't mention when you order) that will literally be gone in 4 sips?
4. Is your idea of restaurant ambiance to decorate with stuff found in the dumpster behind Goodwill? 

If you answered yes to one or more of these questions, then this might be the place for you. I, for one, was not impressed. I went there last night and, while the drink I had was OK, it definitely wasn't worth $12 and I am annoyed that this wasn't explained upfront. Also annoyed that the waiter spilled half my bowl of soup in my lap then didn't bring me a new bowl or even comp the soup. That's not the kind of service that inspires me to return. 

As for the regular food, I can't really speak to it because they had James, owner of the Pittsburgh Taco Truck, as guest chef. His tacos are awesome so I definitely recommend catching his truck. Just get your tacos there, not Bar Marco. They'll be a cpl dollars cheaper too, because they'll be lacking the side of pretentiousness.
Went back to Bar Marco two weeks ago on a Pittsburgh visit. Still as charming, still delicious and interesting food. This will be a destination on each trip back.

Would go back for brunch again, for sure!!
I didn't have much at all to eat there, I ordered potatoes with hollandaise and it was soooo good. 
They have fancy drinks too, which were great.  I love fancy drinks.
BURGER!! Light espresso coat, cast iron pan seared crispy, buttery sturdy bun. Dont miss this one. Also the pork tonnato appetizer.

Came here for Sunday brunch without reservations and was not disappointed.

We were very kindly greeted and quickly offered glasses of champagne while we waited for a table (about 10 minutes) - so sweet!  

The brunch selection was fairly limited but our food was great (Pork Belly eggs benedict) and the drinks were delicious as well.  Nothing to complain about as far as service goes.  I will most certainly be back for dinner and for happy hour.

Oh, please. Might be a good place for drinks, but it was a bust for brunch. When you occupy an historic building you might think you go for a look that's either charming or edgy, and Bar Marco is neither. Tables are small, chairs not all that comfortable, the servers lean toward pretense and away from professionalism -- flatware but no napkins? Who does that? My friend asked for decaf and got a "no" dripping with sarcasm, as if to say, "we don't treat our beans that way." On to the food: the Bloody Mary was good, if skimpy. A dish billed as fried chicken with dandelion greens, topped with a fried egg -- yeah, screw heart disease -- consisted of two overly crusted and overly fried thighs completely concealing a half-dozen threads of wilted-to-death greens. When you have guest chefs, you can't hang crap food on the kitchen because they can simply blame the guest. I know this approach is trendy but it's a bad idea because the secret of every solid restaurant is consistency, Cute idea, though, cute location, cute clientele, but if I want to eat cute, I'll trim my Chia Pet and skip Bar Marco.

Great service and food. Let Jason, the bartender/mixologist, guide you on a cocktail journey. Pick your poison and specify any flavors you do/don't like including sweetness level.. I've never been disappointed, and I have entrusted my beverage palate in his capable hands many times. I could dine on the cheesy, toothsome arancini alone, but the old world pasta and entree recipes are always too intriguing to pass up.

Absolutely enamored with Bar Marco. I'm here at least once a month -- whenever I have visitors in town, I bring them here. The food is delicious and Chef is always cooking up something new! The menu changes seasonally and caters to local availability.  You can eat upstairs in their bar room or downstairs for a special 6 course meal. Their wine selection is limited but impeccable (it's paired with current dishes) and their no-menu bar/bartenders are phenomenal... just tell them what you like and they will whip something up. (For example, A "bourbon + citrus" order is my favorite). Also love that they pay their staff a salary - menu items are priced accordingly as tip is included. The staff is wonderful and rounds out the experience beautifully. Highly recommended for Brunch or Dinner!!

Had a brunch reservation but still had to wait 15 minutes for our table. The host did bring is a small treat to eat in the mean time which was great. There were four of us, but we were sat at a two top table. Very crowded and right on next to the people next to us. They don't have high chairs or boosters so we had to bring our own. No "kids" menu. Ordered pancakes for the kids to split. They were $9 and very small. One child could have eaten the entire order. I had the burger which was very good. Husband had the Benedict which was also good. Food was overpriced no question.

I visited Bar Marco this past week and I have to say I was genuinely impressed. I want to touch on  a few of the things that really stood out to me, and which I felt justified the 5 star rating.

Ambiance - Bar Marco sells itself as a bar/restaurant/art gallery/(soon to be) cigar lounge. At first hearing this I was skeptical that it could manage all of these personas at once, but the delivery is fantastic. For the art: surrounding the bar and dining area there are works by local artists, the entire upper floor is an art gallery, and they're constantly rotating in new pieces to keep it fresh. The bar is handmade by the owners of the restaurant, and it's truly a very nice piece of carpentry. If you have an eye for aesthetics and like to soak in some culture while you eat, this is the place.

Food - While their menu is limited, it's justified in its brevity. Most of the dishes Bar Marco serves are hors d'oeuvre sized, and are great for sharing with a group. This adds to the lively atmosphere in that you're not solely engaged in your one dish, you're constantly passing around the medley of interesting and delicious dishes to sample and enjoy. It can be a little pricey, but you get what you pay for.

Service - When I visited; I was with a group of 10 other college students. From experience, groups such as this are usually served last as they are stereotyped as being rowdy and cheap. We did not experience this at Bar Marco. We were served very quickly, the food and drinks kept coming, and multiple waiters ensured that we were being treated well. At no point did it appear to me that other diners were being neglected; everyone seemed very pleased with their meals. 

All in all, Bar Marco is a great place for dinner and drinks if you're looking for something a bit classier than what you'd usually expect in Pittsburgh. The crowd is very diverse, and the restaurant would appeal to anyone who enjoys fine dining in a casual setting. I anticipate returning frequently during the rest of my time studying in Pittsburgh.

Changing menu based on available good stuff, bar marco has that old world italian simplicity down with a great palate. Everything we tried was top notch. New owners make it more open and with a friendly but slightly classy atmosphere, but it's not a place you go in if you are in a rush. Like in Italy...take your time here.

This place is a must for anyone looking for amazing food with an amazing staff. I've always sat at the bar but there is plenty of cozy seating for a large party if needed. Ask for Alec - he is a whiz at making drinks and extremely knowledgeable!

Had a terrible experience- the food was mediocre and the service was terrible.  We ordered cocktails and I asked for Vodka and recieved gin and the same happened for 2 others in our party. One person ordered a burger and it came out undercooked and when she sent it back the waiter threw a fit and then did not bring her another meal. At the end she had to tell him not to charge her for her meal- I had the trout and it was alright but the whole experience overshadowed the food. This was not worth the money.

Perfect experience! Food was delicious with a signature flare. Fair Prices, perfect portions, wonderful bar selections. Knowledgeable staff, friendly, helpful. Never felt rushed. Can't wait to return.

Dinner tonight was really pleasant, starting from the rosé sampling we were offered upon arriving just because, as our waiter told us, "Rosé is fun!" Our opening dish was the arancini, which was delicately fried and plated on top of a truly delicious pork ragu. The pate board was flavorful with some clever accouterments (sweet apple butter, savory whipped butter, and aggressively pickled red onions are among the most memorable). The Marco Burger at $12 would be worth $21+ in New York; while it is undeniably tasty, I'm a purist when it comes to burgers (aka the simple the better). For me, the burger's thick cut bacon gets in the way of experiencing the patty, espresso, and rosemary aioli. We also ordered the patatas bravas that came drizzled with a sharp chili aioli. 

Service was welcoming and low-key. Try to avoid getting seated next to the door when the temperature is low because the curtains that block the door do little to block the cold drafts that swoop in. Will be coming back to take further advantage of all the smart innovating that Bar Marco has been up to! (P.S Bar Marco's "no-tip" policy begins in April 2015.)

Started going there for No Menu Monday.  It's pretty sweet that different cooks get to come in and impress.  

But their own fare's really good too.  One of the best burgers I've had in Pittsburgh.

Nice brunch in a cool fire-house like building tucked away in part of the Strip District that's not *too* crazy.  Top marks for the lemon ricotta pancakes and the cheesy grits with mushrooms and quail egg.  Nice brunch cocktails too!

So this place is really cute and intimate. It's about as small as they come, so I could see that being an issue if you are trying to go with a large group. Very quaint and simple atmosphere. 

As for the food... I am quite surprised by how much people like it! My brother had the quiche, and it was about the smallest meal I have ever seen in my life. I got the fried chicken, and it was flavorless. My friend had the burger, and it was very average. Cinnamon pull-apart bread was very good, but I think it's hard to screw up a cinnamon roll.

The alcoholic coffee (can't remember the name of it) was recommended by the waitress and was NASTY. Do NOT get it- I drank about two sips of it and let it sit there.

Honestly, for what you pay, everything just seemed so incredibly average. Even the way the food is presented... There's just nothing special about it. I will say that if I had to go again, I would try the pancakes or the corque BLT because they both looked amazing. 

I am interested to go for dinner, because it might be a lot better, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it to a friend for brunch.

Great food and drinks.  When I went here for brunch the accidentally forgot about my entree, which was annoying but sometimes happens.  They ended up comping something for me (I can't remember if it was my drink or the entree itself).  Regardless, I would come back here because everything was yummy and the staff was friendly.  I also inquired about hosting an event here many months ago and the event coordinator was always responsive and thorough in our e-mail communications.

Food was ok but not what it is hyped up to be. The service was horrible. Our server was a pompous asshole who treated us like shit. This guy needs to find a job where he is not waiting on people. He made multiple mistakes by not getting something we ordered and blamed us for it. His reply was. " I didn't realize you wanted that." He refused to recommend anything, as he stated, " I have no idea what you like so it would be impossible for me to recommend something"  He was argumentative about everything. Every time we asked a question he came back with some smart ass answer. I can only assume that he's like this all the time because he was so accustomed to being disrespectful. He told us that the items are larger as you go down the menu from top to bottom. My 14 year old daughter said, "Dad my salad was bigger than my dinner." He told us that the Caesar Salad was an Authentic Caesar Salad and the anchovies could not be removed. Ok great I get that, but the salad is nothing like an Authentic Caesar Salad. My Father was serving table side Caesar Salads in his restaurants since the 60's, the whole deal with egg, evoo, garlic, Dijon, etc. and let me tell you this was not an authentic Caesar. Maybe a stab at a new hip take on an Authentic Caesar with a swing and miss. There was so much anchovies in this thing you might as well call it an Anchovies Salad. I asked the server about the temperature perpetration for my steak and if their medium would still have a pink center. With a smirk reply he responded but of coarse. I ended up receiving a well done steak with Zero pink. It looked like it sat under a heat lamp for 10 minutes. The dessert was good! Then, at 6:15pm the server told us that we had to leave because the table was booked for a 6:45pm reservation. We were like ok.... we've been waiting for you to bring us the check. I think he just wanted to get another stab in before we left. A long story short I went to Bar Marco for my Birthday Dinner and was treated like crap by a rude condescending server. I'm in my 40's and I have never been treated like that by a server.

We had a private brunch upstairs after graduation for about 30 people and it was awesome.  The venue is so cool and airy and light and the food was superb.  Loved the corn pancakes and the pasta with cream sauce was incredible.  The service seemed very good and the room was perfect for us.

The service and atmosphere at Bar Marco was more than awesome!  The staff was incredibly personable, and the drinks were some of the most unique combinations I've seen in Pittsburgh. My Gimlet with tequila was delicious! The "snacks" that we enjoyed were amazing and prepared perfectly. The carrots and mushrooms in the frito miso were the best beer battered anythings I've ever had. I'd expect that this place is going to be extremely hard to get into in a month or two. Go now! And experience how great this place is. I'm going back for sure! Thanks guys!

This is a small place packed with big flavor....from the drinks to the food.  The craft cocktails are enchanting and creative made by a bartender who truly considers drink making an art...which makes sitting at the very small bar a true treat.  The food is fresh and excellently prepared.  The menu changes each day (with a few standards....like the Arancini....which is the best I have ever had!).  The service is top notch.  They have a no-tip policy which they are sure to remind you of (classy!).  All in all, time spent at Bar Marco is memorable, delightful and delicious.  GO!

Bar Marco is the strip's best kept secret.  

We went with a group of 6 for the first time on a Tuesday and we were not disappointed. We liked it so much we had to come back for the following Tuesday. 

Tuesday nights some of their menu items are $6 including their nifty cocktails and the Marco Burger. It was busy both nights, so if you decide to make a trip plan on making it an evening. 

Seating is a quaint room with tables and a small bar with dim lighting and candlelight. The edges of the room are lined with various wine bottles and a couple choice art pieces. Music is usually playing as well. Definitely a cool vibe for a night out with friends. 

The service is awesome, the staff are friendly and seem to genuinely care that you enjoy every part of your experience. 

The food- you can't come here without trying the Marco burger, one of the tastiest burgers I've eaten. The beef was juicy, flavorful, and cooked perfectly. The patatas bravas were great as a side to share with the table as well.

The cocktails- you can definitely come here and make an evening trying their different cocktails. They have a rotating cocktail menu and make sure to pack a punch. If you can, try the Bees Knees and The Bitter End. 

I may just become a regular here.

Excellent service, food, and cocktails!  Bartender was friendly and loved the atmosphere, and the food was delicious.  Had the charcuterie plate, which had a really good bean dip with it, then a salad and the lamb fettuccine.  Homemade pasta was perfect!  Definitely go here, you won't regret it!

Drinks are amazing, especially if you are a fan of interesting cocktails. Food has been consistently good every time we have been. Portions are on the smaller side, but interesting enough that I don't mind the price. 

My only grievance is the service. I love this place and will continue to frequent them; however, I would never expect quick and attentive service at Bar Marco.

Brunchy brunch brunch brunch.  I'm a sucker, a real sucker for cocktails and cured salmon on a Sunday.  All they had to do was post photos to facebook and offer champagne to the first 20 reservations and voila! I had a reservation for 6 for the inauguration day for brunch.  I do LOVE places that keep their Facebook/website like super up-to-date!  Much appreciated!!

This place is cool.  It's cool for evening cocktails, appetizers, happy hour, or brunch.  It is also slightly "cold" as in, the acoustics.  It can be difficult to hear the person next to you when you turn your head.  Everything is like, concrete, tin, marble, tile, etc.

The tables and bar are nicely placed and the menu has prices and is easy to read.  There were no cocktails listed on the brunch menu, though, which I didn't really like, but since I've been for drinks before, I kind of knew what they had.  The sangria was small, but it was only $5 (but sangria is a cheap drink...)

I got the whiskey cured salmon.  It comes with cream cheese and capers and rye bread.  It was good, but a very small portion for $13.  I left hungry.  The risotto looked delicious.  A friend got the yogurt with an extra egg and she seemed to enjoy it.  They did bring out a complimentary little cup of the yogurt with apple slices before hand, which was nice, but we had no spoons!  I asked for spoons about twice and never got them.  Then someone picked up our yogurts before we were ever able to eat it :(

The service is friendly (I've been once for cocktails and it was great service at the bar), but it was a little "first time-y", with the little things.  For example, we had a water jug, but no water glasses.  Then we had glasses but no more water. Had to ask a few times for it before we took a jug from an empty table.  The sangria took a good 20 min to get.  The food also took a while, but it was their first time, so that's understandable I guess.

I hope that they improve.  I'd give the brunch 3 stars and the regular hours 4-5 stars.  I'd also love to see the patio that they are planning.  I think this place has tons of potential.

Dear Bar Marco, get it together-really together, very soon!  The Pittsburgh market is getting competitive for these kinds of places and I don't want you to be left out with bad reviews!  You're right at the edge of not being new anymore and going to lose people with a bad experience.  I will be back, but I'd like it to be a go-to place and it's not quite there yet.  Alchemy N Ale is a prime example of a great place that just fell off at the beginning and may not recover.

Had dinner last night and was extremely impressed with the service at the table and the high level of flexibility in the kitchen.  One of our party is on a low sodium diet and the chef created a pasta dish that was not only delicious but met the sodium requirement.  The other three diners were equally impressed.  We'll be back.  Many times.

Wow!  Food was amazing. Service was top notch. And the living wage / no-gratuity policy -- while requiring some getting used to -- makes me feel so 5 stars about this place. 

The server really knew his stuff, probing our tastes to help recommend wine and then food. The sommelier came by to check how we liked the wine and was clearly smart and into his job. Both the server and the sommelier knew when to check in and when to leave us alone. 

The gemelli beef sugo was rich and to die for. The pan seared chicken with the black beans was out of this world (and let's be honest, why order chicken when you're out at a nice place, right?  It's usually gonna be dry and bland, but nooooo, this amazed.  The beet greens with some sort of cheesy thing on top was delicious. And our dessert (chocolate + coffee, which sounds like just chocolate and coffee, but it's not!), which we split, was a perfect wrap up for the meal. 

Not cheap but not too pricey. A little noisy and close to other customers (depending on your table) but the service and the food propped these issues up to 5 stars, no question. We'll be back.

Bar Marco had delicious food. The burger and pork dishes were the top picks at our table. I had the pasta,bacon, and Apple dish and felt it was over salted. However, the service here makes it not worth the visit. We had reservations for 11:30 and we didn't get seated till 45 min after this. The drinks made the wait bearable but the mixed drinks were over priced and coffees were not refilled with out chasing down a waiter. Once we were sat we never we asked if we wanted new drinks. A quick brunch with friends ended up being 3 hrs. In summary, awesome food but terrible service.

I was very hesitant going into this spot for two reasons, 1) cost, as I had heard that the staff is salaried and thus you don't tip; I figured the cost of the food would reflect that, and 2) an acquaintance had terrible service there before, according to him.

We met there for dinner with a couple. I tried to call to make a reservation for 7 but j was informed they could take us at 8. I wasn't sure it would work for our friends so I promised to call back. I tried to call back to confirm but it went to voicemail; I left a really awkward voicemail. In the meantime I found out my husband has already made reservations. I called back and left a 2nd awkward voicemail . I received a call back and took the opportunity to say nevermind and apologize for my excessive awkwardness in 2 voicemails, ha! The caller, who we found out was the manager, was incredibly sweet and patient. We joked about poor husband/wife communication and how we both were recently married... 2 weeks prior. 

When we arrived, they gave us complimentary champagne to say congrats. Even though other tables were there, they made us feel like we were the only guests. They were so nice, so attentive, and had great suggestions. 

The venue is small and has really quirky decorations and the best mood lighting.

The food was pricey but not anymore than any of the other restaurants we like to frequent. The food was very tasty! The only thing is that portions are exponentially smaller, but not too small. I actually prefer smaller portions , as I hate the feeling of being stuffed.

During dessert my husband asked for Porto which they did not have. Instead they brought a few aperitifs and digestives for us to sample and we got to make conversation with the staff as we sample different bitters. 

Truly a great experience!

Visited Bar Marco for the first time on National Wine Day. Didn't know anything about the bar, just wanted some wine. To my fortune, the bartender, Jason, was phenomenal and helpful. He suggested an amazing wine selection. After some conversation and his will power to convenience the kitchen to make a cheese plate, which wasn't on the menu, he made me an outstanding off the wall single Scotch cocktail. So to summarize, the staff and service make this place a gem. That said, as a business traveler and out-of-towner, this place is great to all tastes.

Last Friday we were able to score a last minute reservation at Bar Marco and I'm so glad we did! When Googling "Best Cocktails in Pittsburgh" or "Must-Do Restaurants", Bar Marco shows up on a number of lists, so naturally it made our "Weekend Restaurants List".

The atmosphere is extremely quaint and authentic to the original firehouse it used to be. All the staff (who are salaried by the way) were friendly, prompt, and so informative of the menu, especially Dom, who manages their small but great wine list. I opted for a delicious Rose while my boyfriend experimented with "Bartender's Choice" and different whiskeys - both were excellent 3 glasses later.

Food wise: We started with the Focaccia, which was absolutely delicious and the Arancini, which was meh. The arancini balls were filled with yellow spanish rice and in ours for some reason, no beef ragu like the menu stated. The San Marzano tomato sauce that accompanied the arancini was flavorful, but they don't measure up to true italian arancini.

For dinner, I got the Spinach Gnudi which in look and texture was similar to pale green play-doh balls. The texture is quite interesting and way more dough-y than gnocchi with little to no flavor. Probably wouldn't get this again. The other entree we tried was the hanger steak, again good but nothing I'd rave about after leaving the restaurant.


Overall: a great place to knock off the list if you enjoy being creative with your cocktails or want a light meal - stick to the apps and shared pasta dishes.

Visited on 12/26/2013. The current online menu is from 11/12/2013. 4 of 20 items were the same.  

Meat plate
Cheese plate
Meat/Cheese plate
Burger

Restaurants, an online menu makes sense when it's updated! 

Odd door-front curtains. It's a cool entrance but corny from inside.. is it to separate crammed dining room from those waiting? It sticks out, and Bar Marco is more a dim-lit+high chatter+blend-in vibe. Dark with a stifling dash of hipster.

Service was slammed, one guy working the 8 tables out front. Our second round of drinks took 25 minutes. He apologized before we could comment when he dropped the check, so they're good enough to realize it. Descriptions were on-point 75%, occasional stuttering and stammering when questioned. 

The bar is novelty. "We have no cocktail menu" she challenged with a smirk. Game on! Drink #1 was awesome, ordered in person. Drink #2 was third-person via waiter, and it came out with 2/5 the ingredients asked for. Conclusion: SIT AT THE 6-PERSON BAR, WHOLE MEAL. That said, neither drink was more standout than a good cocktail from a printed-menu.. anticipate that novelty wearing thin on return trips.

Food is decent at best, mix of tapas and classy bar. Cheese plate is a cheese plate, the earthy honey and jalapeno jelly the highlight. The fried smelt needs more lime and salt, the fish arguably too delicate for frying though the light mayo cuts the oil well. The tartare is well-diced with few clumps but way over-spiced, cumin masking the meal. The bolognese was bland and the sauce watery with chemical hints. Definitely could do with more salt and another minute on the noodles.

If the bar is one reason I'd return, the pork belly is the other. Everyone does pork belly these days. Bar Marco actually does it right: perfectly crisp edge with the piping hot sticky gob of fat melting in your mouth. No "sour" per the menu, but the definite highlight. Adult candy.

The food is delicious. But we had terrible service. We had a reservation for 5 for brunch. Upon sitting we were asked if we wanted coffee, but not offered anything else. Our water was never refilled until we asked. It took about 40 minutes to get out food, and one order was completely forgotten about. So we waited another 15 minutes for that. While we were waiting for that last order, our spacey server asked how everything was and we replied "just waiting in the other order" and he goes "excellent." Uh, what? We were not asked if we wanted refills on our bloody Mary's either. The only saving grace was the food was good. I hope they step up their game with the service. Not impressed at all.

Great food, very Poor service. I have to say that this is disappointing. I am a fan of the general atmosphere and setting of this restaurant. While well disguised now, it was once a Pittsburgh Fire Department station and later housed a well known Pittsburgh Advertising agency. I have had 2 negative experiences at Bar Marco, none involving the food. The food is near exceptional but the service taints it heavily. I visited last week with 3 co-workers / clients. Our waiter ( his name begins with a 'D' ) started out okay. Once it came time to take our 4 orders ( 4 of us ordering multiple courses ) he chose to write nothing down. When a couple of us changed our minds mid-stream he was visibly and verbally annoyed with us. I opted to ask for him to pre-package half of my entree to eliminate any temptation I might have to consume the entire high calorie plate. D protested, agitated and angrily, but when I stood firm, he relented. Again visibly and vocally annoyed. I suppose with their 'no tipping' system this is what we all might come to expect? Restaurant owners unable to incentivize their staff to treat customers courteously at all times, and wait staff that loses sight of ( or just doesn't care about ) the importance of the customer to the establishment. I have not looked at tipping as the customer footing the payroll of the staff. I saw it as a system of checks and balances that evolved to protect the customer and the proprietor while giving the staff an opportunity to make more pay by providing better service. IMHO This is one area of consumer experience that may well have done without being 're-imagined', and Bar Marco is suffering for it.

Update Feb 2018. I have gone back and given them another shot. Like I said, the atmosphere is great ( almost like a speak easy ) and the food stellar. This time we had nothing but great service and attitude from the staff. I'm hoping it is this way for everyone now. I added a star with cautious optimism. I will return again soon.

Some time has passed since my previous review of Bar Marco, so I thought it was worth updating. My previous enthusiasm for Bar Marco remains in place; in fact, I'd say I'm even more excited about this fine little bar/restaurant now than I was last time. Bar Marco is a unique option in Pittsburgh's increasingly sophisticated and diverse food and drink landscape. Put simply, it is great and the guys should keep up the great work they are doing. This is fast-becoming a happening joint that I suspect isn't just for the neighborhood (there can't be that many people living in the Strip, and Cioppino's bar still seems packed on Friday and Saturday evenings with the older set from the Cork Factory). People are coming from other neighborhoods, which is a good sign.

I've dedicated myself to a very rigorous review process of Bar Marco. That has meant going on an almost weekly basis at various times of the day and night (and, one time, twice on one day). This grueling (but rigorous) approach means that I have tried most of the drinks, most of the dishes, and seen the place in various "moods" depending on the day of the week and the time of day or night. I like all the food and all the drinks. But maybe I'm easy to please. 

What's impressive about Bar Marco is that they have managed to create a friendly, welcoming environment that can also be a hot spot on busy Friday and Saturday (late) nights. Under those conditions Bar Marco becomes a very cool bar filled to capacity with "Pittsters" (Pittsburgh hipsters) and beautiful people (but in a good way).  It is a very happening (and loud--also in a good way) room. Creating a vibe that can be cutting edge while remaining friendly and neighborhoodly requires some skill and effort, and reminds me of places in cities like New York and Paris that morph into various states of existence and moods throughout the course of the day or, in Bar Marco's case, evening. In conducting my rigorous research for this review I planted myself for many hours to observe how the mood changes from early evening (relaxed, after-work drinks and snacking, mostly) to late evening (the aforementioned sophisticated and "happening" bar vibe). I've also observed it at weekend brunch (relaxed), into the afternoon (still relaxed) and then evening (see above).

It should also be noted that Bar Marco seems to be learning as they go and evolving their menu and service. If you went a while ago in their earlier days, I highly recommend a revisit. In fact, why not try something akin to my clearly scientifically rigorous sampling of this fine establishment at different times to see for yourself how it transforms with the day and time, as well as the people enjoying themselves.
A warm and classy staff. Always go above and beyond to make sure one's experience is enjoyable. Michael always knows the perfect libation, and when to offer it. Love this establishment,

Love what these guys are doing, love the room and love the events they are holding upstairs.  Hate that sometimes even with a reservation you have to wait, but usually one of those charmers smooths it over with a glass champagne and some friendly conversation.  

The no-menu mondays are something I want to get to more of, the collaborations with the Pgh Taco Truck and other awesome chefs around the city is such a cool idea.  The service, quality of food on the ever changing menu and the ambiance are always fabulous.  I wish the bar was little bigger but then I guess you wouldn't get all the personalized attention when you sat there.  When you are paying for quality food and drinks, the quality service should always match, here it really does.

Our group of 5 had a great experience. 
We came with a reservation for 10:30am for Saturday, yes, Saturday morning brunch. We had a delicious sampling of four different pastry delights. The perfect cider donuts with a light caramel sauce and sweet cream on the side 
(a must), the flaky scones with a pear butter that was also fantastic with the donuts. The croissant was excellent and the quiche was among the best I've had ever (phenomenal crust and whipped eggs which created a light and airy quiche to be sought after). 
I enjoyed the espresso bacon burger for brunch today. Awesome! I have never had a burger for brunch, and with all the sweet and savory samples we tried, I thought I would explore beyond my norm for brunch. It was an appropriate size and made precisely to my desire (finished medium). Everyone ordered something different and all of it looked great. The service was attentive and knowledgable about the menu as well as the sourcing of the ingredients. 
The menus are seasonal and reflect what is available locally at the time of your visit. 
And visit you must! 
I would recommend adding at least one vegan option for people who have dietary restrictions to round out the menu, but I couldn't reduce your stars on that account alone since it doesn't effect me, but one of my party enjoyed a mimosa rather than eat due to this issue. She didn't ask about any off menu options to accommodate her situation so I can't blame the restaurant or fault the staff for that. I would guess that the kitchen staff would have whipped up something delicious for her had she troubled them with the question.

I probably would give this place a worse rating,  but I did like the setting and the drinks.  The food was decent,  but don't come hungry,  the portions are very small.  The service wasn't that great for 20 people being in the restaurant either.  I wouldn't go back here,  there's much better places around.

My daughter and I were trying to decide where to eat dinner last night. She went to the Pittsburgh Magazine website and looked at their list. She picked out a couple places that we wanted to try. We chose a restaurant in the Strip, since we were first going to Lawrenceville. As we drove past our first choice, we saw the line out the door and down the street. Waiting was not an option for our stomachs on this night. We pulled off so she could make another choice. She said Bar Marco, but it's pricier. OK, we'll splurge. We backtracked up the street and found it. It was about 5 PM, and the place was empty except for a couple people at the bar and one table of patrons. We did not have a reservation but were seated. We sat one table away from steps going to the 2nd floor. The menu was small which can be helpful in making selections. Too much choice can be overwhelming. We decided to start with arancini and the focaccia. The arancini was delicious with a tasty sauce. The focaccia was also quite good, although the dipping olive oil was strong for my taste.  For the entree, my daughter ordered the pork loin with brussels sprouts and sweet potatoes. She told me I could have the brussels sprouts. What I got was one small taste. She said they didn't taste cabbagey, and ate them all. She told the server she was now a fan of their brussels sprouts. I ordered the rigatoni with beef shank. It was cooked perfectly 'al dente' with the sauce of that beef shank. I would have liked just a bit more juice in the sauce. My daughter insisted I try a bite of her sweet potatoes before they were gone. They were just the right sweetness and flavor to meld with the pork loin. We actually did not share meals at all, just a taste. The portions for entrees are much smaller than we may be accustomed to, but they really are just the right size. They fill but do not overfill. We just get used to equating bigger size with greater value. Even though I had some leftovers to take home (trying to make that trip to the gym earlier in the day mean something), we ordered dessert. Again, the dessert menu was short. My daughter and I decided to share a dessert, so we went with her first choice-the pistachio cake with a cup of Commonplace coffee. I joked with our server that years ago I made a pistacihio cake with a cake mix and box of pistachio pudding. She laughed and replied that it would be just like that. It was delivered by another server who explained each element of the presentation. Despite its small appearance, again it was just enough for the two of us after our meal. We ate each bite with a piece of other plate elements (pear gelee, florentine cookie, dot of raspberry sauce, the cream and pistachios). We were not disappointed in any of the food we ordered here. If I could change something on the menu, it would be to offer a couple 'normal' drinks. My daughter wanted a soda, but they had only handcrafted sodas. I asked about iced tea, but that also was not an offering. I ordered a handcrafted lemon drink which was a bit too gingery. The server did take it back to sweeten a bit. She was very accommodating and helpful. 

We struck up a conversation with a couple who came in after us and were seated at the table at the bottom of the long staircase leading to the second floor. The stairs offered a mysterious air to the space. What's up there? It was this couple's first time also at Bar Marco. They ordered the osso buco and the bucatini & lobster. They told us they were both happy with their choices. We were a step ahead of them, so they saw our dessert arrive. They watched our reaction to that first taste, and then asked about it.  We assured them it was delicious and the other choices were probably good too. For them watching us gave more evidence of the experience of fellow diners.  

The space here is small and not fancy. I noticed our fellow diner look at the chips on the pasta bowl, and then realized my bowl was also chipped. Earlier I noticed the glasses at the table beside us did not match. I assume these things are deliberate in the presentation. The ceiling is high and the door opens from the street to the dining area. The entrance is encased by heavy curtains hanging on steel pipe. There is just enough opening in those curtains to enter the main dining area. This rigging helps to protect diners from that cold air burst as the front door opens. Still I felt a draft and sat with my coat around my shoulders during the meal. The diners at that table next to the steps mentioned a draft from that staircase also.  

My daughter and I enjoyed every bite of our meals, and we plan to return again on a splurge. Perhaps next trip it will be for brunch. .

We went here recently to celebrate a friend's birthday. This place is cool and has a lot of potential. I appreciate their inventiveness and general commitment to quality materials.  The cocktails are top-notch and the selection of spirits is broad. We did a lot of sampling from the menu and pretty much everything we ate was delicious. The only awkward part of the tapas-style menu is that we had no clue how much food to order. Don't get me wrong, the staff was helpful and did not mind when we ordered additional items after our first batch -- it seems that's what's expected -- but it just made us feel a little adrift in the menu, not really understanding how large the portions were and how many things we should decide on.  It probably does a brain good to periodically reevaluate what constitutes a meal.  On a logistical note, the menu changes all the time, and different members of our party had different versions of the menu. The server did not seem extremely concerned when we informed her of this. Luckily, no one tried to order anything that wasn't actually available that day. We liked everything we ordered. I've already returned once for cocktails at the bar. Also, as far as dessert goes, get the olive oil cake if they have it that day! One of the tastiest desserts ever!
We had a great meal here and some great drinks. I really enjoyed the open front door letting in the breeze- nice ambiance. We were able to order gluten free - very helpful.

We went for brunch on a Saturday. The food was very tasty! I got the scramble with capers and my friends got a Benedict, mushroom soup and potatoes with hollandaise, Everything was yummy and the cocktails were great! The server talks to you about what you like then concord something from your preferences. We would have gotten more than two each if it weren't for the slow service. 
This is where bar Marco looses a star. Really they should lose 2 but the food was so good and the drinks so tasty I am only deducting one.
They have recently switched to paying all their servers a living wage and benefits so you don't need to tip. I would heartily support this if our service hadn't been so poor. The guy was very nice and friendly but he took forever to get to us and then u sat around with an empty glass wanting another drink too often and for too long.
It was busy, but the not that busy. Maybe when you don't work for tips you don't have to care about good service. 
I really love that they pay their people a living wage, but for the price I paid for brunch (even factoring in the tip) I really expect better service.
Food was good but way overpriced. You get miniture portions, and I mean laughably miniture for what you pay for.

This review is for the drinks and the space only. The space is a lovely open room with a great classic tile floor. The cocktails were extremely good matched on my short trip to Pittsburgh only by those at the Butcher and the Rye.

Never even made it past the door... walked in today (Sunday 9/10/17) around 12:10pm... the host greets us at the door, confirms it's just the two of us, then proceeds to ask if we have a reservation.  We say no reservation.  He looks around the room, which has at least five (5) open tables of varying sizes, he looks at his reservations, then tells us they are full with reservations until 1pm.  The host then smiles at us and doesn't move.   Awkward silence moment.  With five open tables in sight, Me and my lady are looking at him like like, you are not even going to try to find us somewhere to sit?!?!  With no further acknowledgment from this host, we turn and leave.  Two customers lost forever. 

If Sundays are reservation only, you need to list that somewhere in the restaurant AND on the website.  To quickly turn away two patron without any effort to figure something out to keep their money in the door... piss poor people skills and piss poor management.

Would give this place 10 stars if i could!! Can't stop talking about this place to everyone! Super cool vibe - I think it used to be an old firehouse (?) but it has a very industrial interior, hipster-y feel, and the workers there are all SO GENUINELY NICE. Service was amazing - did I mention that this is a no gratuity restaurant? The price definitely reflects the no-gratuity part, because it is a little bit on the higher end, but totally worth it. Also read online that the staff here receive a salary and health benefits - seriously, who wouldn't want to support that? 

Came here with a small group for Saturday brunch - drinks were delicious, the server was so attentive, and the food was amazing! Seriously can't wait for my next weekend off with friends to come here again. HIGHLY recommend this place to anyone visiting PGH for the weekend. Make sure you get the potatoes with the hollandaise sauce to start! I got the baked eggs here and since then, I've been trying to imitate the recipe (with not much luck :'D). My friend got the burger with fried egg and was talking about it for days after - which says a lot, since she is very particular with her food! Also the waiter gave me a large plate of salad on the side for free :D Gotta have my veggies. Ty! Would recommend e-mailing for reservation in advance in case there's a wait.

Terrible experience at this restaurant. Ordered a scotch that was double the price of the best restaurant in Pittsburgh. Hors d'oeuvres were also poor but expensive, have no idea how this place survives.

Customer service was pathetic.  We will never be coming back here again.
Amazing drinks! Amazing food! Amazing art! This is the perfect place to find a great dispora of creative people- from artists to tech to bankers! The owners are super cute too!

(See update below for a more recent assessment)

Between 3 and 4 stars. 4 stars for the effort, and because it's a new place. 3 for the service and cocktails that can improve a bit. 

Small, but nice crowd on Saturday evening. Our party of 4 was able to find a table to sit and drink, and the bar was not too noisy. Does not happen in every bar in Pittsburgh. Not the undergrad crowd, which is definitely a plus (say 25+).

Service was a tad deficient. It was hard to get the attention of the staff, and it took them a while to serve us. On the other hand, the staff is very friendly. 

Their gimlet could be stronger and less watery (start with less ice, perhaps - also I am not entirely sure about the red pepper in it), but the manhattan was good. The list of cocktails is small. A longer list would be nice. 

The price is right for this kind of place. Most cocktails are around $8-10.

*Update* 10/2012: I've been back there a few times, and overall I still like it, but I now have a more detailed views of what to like and what to dislike there. 

what's to like: The list of cocktails has grown very much since I was there. It's now substantial, and some of the cocktails are hits. Go for it, try, retry, and reretry.

What's ok: The appetizers are still fine, although not extraordinary. Their bacon +dates are dry, and surely not worth $10. Their cold cuts are very good on the other hand.

What's to dislike: I ate there recently, and I was under impressed. Based on my food (pork shoulder), I'd give only 2 stars. Surely not worth the $20 or so I paid for it. 

Upshot: I'll be back for cocktails, and probably for cheese and cold cuts. I'll skip the food. So will you if you are wise.

Pretentious and incompetent - sadly that seems to be the consensus of many reviews here. They are trying way too hard to be too cool for school without even remotely being able to pull it off. 

We were in town from Brooklyn (and therefore very familiar with the type of place Bar Marco aspires to be) and had heard great things. We tried to call ahead but nobody picked up the phone because they are too self-consciously hip to take reservation the normal way ("send us a text and we'll reply within 24hours" - wtf kind of reservation system is that?) 

We arrived to a half-empty room and were kept waiting at the bar with the promise of a table "within 15-20mins" - no problem, happy to wait. A full hour and 10mins later (during which 3 two-tops had been sitting empty THE WHOLE TIME with waiters skulking around looking clueless) we were told they couldn't accommodate us but we could eat at the bar, which is way too narrow to eat comfortably. 

Dudes, we could have finished our whole dinner at any of the three tables by now! You're a casual bar, not some white-glove 3-Star Michelin place, just put the plates down on the table and quit acting like anyone should consider themselves lucky to be able to spend money here. 

Bottom line: like many a place with good press they've since fallen into the trap of believing their own hype and are now in the attitude business rather than the hospitality business. But acting all snooty doesn't quite work when half your tables are sitting empty - that's called an incompetent front of house crew. Get your shit together Kevin - seriously disappointing.

We had our wedding reception here on 10/22/2016. After losing our original venue and finding Bar Marco, this ended up being a blessing. From the first e-mail everyone was wonderful, especially Andrew and Brogan. We fell in love with Union Hall, with the high arched windows, the art on the walls and the charm. But what made the night was the people who work at Bar Marco, they are amazing. They were as much a part of our wedding celebration as any guest there. So accommodating and so nice. They made our night perfect.

And the food, THE FOOD, was amazing. Everyone loved it and couldn't get enough. I'm so happy we found Bar Marco and their team, it truly made our wedding even more special to know we were in good hands.
I've lived in the strip for the past few years and Bar Marco has always been a go to spot. The menu and chefs have changed but they've been great changes.

I'm currently on a two week exploration into restaurants and bars that are new to me, and I keep finding great spots and Bar Marco is a place that I will find myself frequenting.

As someone's review mentioned, the space is a work in progress, but it currently has a industrial style feel to it that I love.  Polished concrete floors, stainless steel bar, unique light fixtures, and glazed brick walls that you cannot find in a newly constructed space.

After a fairly good meal at Andrew's Steakhouse in Rivers Casino (and paying for the meal by playing Roulette after), the idea came into my head to head to Bar Marco after reading a few of the reviews on Yelp, and missing Embers and Fire House Lounge.  The Bar is owned by four friends, that you can tell are having fun with what they do.  We weren't there to eat, but to have a few cocktails, and so I ordered a Perfect Manhattan and told the bartender (Bobby) to use which ever bourbon he preferred.  He instead talked me into having their Bar Marco Manhattan, and gave me the story behind his creation which was based on recreating some famous turn of the century mixologist, but didn't have exactly what the receipt called for so heused what was on hand and came up with the Bar Marco Manhattan.  This was very tasty so for rounds two and three he was given the right to decide what I wanted to drink, which was apparently the Gimblet, and the 'treuse.  The ice melted too fast for the Gimblet because the first few sips were watery, but half way thru it was excellent.  Especially with the red pepper garnish.  The 'treuse was also excellent, and with rosemary incorporated into it it became really exceptional.

As I mentioned we weren't there to eat, but I kept eyeing everyone's food.  And the owner's kept giving me food to try, and I must say it was very good.  Especially the duck...actually I think everything I tried was duck (it must have been the theme of the night)

The atmosphere was great, the drinks were great, but the friendliness and passion of the staff is what will bring me back again.

The one thing that they need for the winter is a way to keep the draft out as the door opens.

Really nice service. We stopped in for a glass of wine, and were presented with several to taste, and also given a complimentary mini-crudité platter. Sat outside because the weather was nice. All around lovely experience. P.S. I've also been here for brunch and would come back :)

I recently had brunch with some friends at Bar Marco for the first time. I had previously read some of the most recent reviews on Yelp before going that complained about the service. I found the service to be up to par and very accommodating. Our reserved table was still occupied when we first arrived. The server greeted us, apologized a couple of times for the wait, and offered us drinks while we waited. 
The food was pretty good, but not the most amazing I've ever had. The bacon appetizer was delicious and all three of us were happy with our brunch entrees- soft scrambled eggs, lemon pancakes, and baked eggs. I would return to try dinner.

My boyfriend and i went there for brunch today and the food was fonominal! He got the quiche and a bloody Mary, the spice in the bloody Mary was on point and the alcohol to juice ratio was great. His quiche was delicious, it was very cheesy and there was a perfect amount of spinach... i had a mimosa and the buttermilk pancakes with bacon. The mimosa was good and the pancakes were delicious! The pear/cherry compote/jam on the pancakes was refreshing and a nice twist on traditional pancakes. The bacon was the absolute best bacon i have ever had.  Just fantastic food and great atmosphere :) i would highly recommend this place if you are in the strip district looking for a bite to eat at a fair price

Brunch at Bar Marco is delicious but the atmosphere and service leave you wanting more. The burger was beautifully seasoned and delicious. The pork was exceptional and the lavender & lemon sticky buns were great! The homemade coffee was also top notch

Drawbacks: Seating was cramped. Service was slow. Not a lot of personality. 

So expect an amazing meal, but leave ample time to enjoy it.

Excellent brunch and very good signature drinks. Bar Marco is unique and hip without coming off as exclusive.  I found the staff to be friendly. The restaurant is small but charming.  At first glance the prices might give you sticker shock, but keep in mind that all prices include gratuity (no tipping).
Good atmosphere and friendly staff.  The plates aren't as big as we were expecting but everything was tasty and well done.  Would definitely go back.

My favorite part about Bar Marco was the "bartenders choice" of the drink list. They have a lot of great wine and cocktail options as it is, but there is so much fun and excitement in picking your spirit and flavors and seeing what the bartender comes up with just for you. If the drink he made me wasn't so unique and custom, it would be my new go-to at any bar.  The bartender himself and our waitress were so knowledgable and friendly. The food is smaller plates, which they tell you ahead of time, but the prices are a little on the higher side--this may be okay because they don't accept gratuity, and this is factored into the price of the food.  The menu typical rotates, but the waitress said they make their pasta and bread all in-house which is a nice touch.  We did make a reservation as other previous reviewers had suggested, but there was plenty of space to sit on this Friday evening.

A destination for a classic cocktail in Pittsburgh.  There are a few places starting to pop up in Pittsburgh, that could be transplanted to any international city and not fit awkwardly into the scene.  Bar Marco is one of the select places...They put quality over quantity and make some great cocktails, to boot! The food is fantastic as well.  The burger at $9, is the best value and best burger in the city. Love that price point! I would highly suggest an evening at Bar Marco for any occasion...romantic, casual, formal, after a show or happy hour.  Great spot. And thank you..NO TV's. Great mood and not pretentious. Enjoy.

The orange-ricotta (or whatever they were) pancakes got this place an extra star...Man, they were good.  

Don't get excited about their online menu- it is not what you will receive when you arrive.

Anywho, I had an idea of where this place was- the old Firehouse Lounge if you're familiar.  Thank goodness two of my friends showed up at the same time as me to confirm- as there is NO signage whatsoever.  We walk in and....hello big thick gray curtains!  I pull one back slightly to reveal a dinner enjoying his meal.  I was literally right on top of this guy!  Note to Bar Marco- get another door or something.  Those curtains are not what's hot.

I didn't love my cocktail- the aperol something or other.  It could have had a little more oomph.  I should consider that it was 1pm and I shouldn't need a super stick drink.  Two people in my group ordered Bloody Mary's that looked more Mary than bloody (not enough juice, or alcohol really).

While the place was tiny, loud and a bit pricey, the saving grace was those pancakes.  Did I mention that they were sold out of most of the stuff we originally ordered?  No bueno.  I probably wouldn't go back.

I'm a simple foods kind of guy.  So I was a little put off on arriving and seeing the menu.  When I told the staff that I had a fruit cup for breakfast, salad for lunch, and was hoping for some meat in my dinner; I was expecting the kind of dismissive attitude my style usually receives.  The bartender looked thoughtful for a moment and said, "You should start with the Pork Loin appetizer and have the steak for your main course."  Needless to say, I was surprised.  In the new wave of Pittsburgh restaurants I have come to expect "an air" to my blue collar roots, and receive it at some places.  I did not here and 

I ended up having the pork loin main course because the pork loin appetizer was mouth watering.  All of my food was delicious.  My drinks were delicious.  The "Iced Irish Coffee" I requested for dessert was a feat of mixing.

This place was a surprise for me.  I love tip free, in my experience the best service I received has been at tip free venues or in tip free countries.

The food was good for the most part, but couldn't eat one of the ingredients and the chef had no clue what to do so just gave me more potatoes.  Slight burned at that . The server/waiter was clueless, had to go get my own water refills a couple of times. Meat was perfectly cooked, but tragically overpriced for bad service.
I was in the Strip last week and noticed that their sign is still just white grease pencil in the window.  You stay classy, guys.

Very hip place... Dress stylish kind of like a fashion show in there but good food and good prices but expensive liquor and beer!
Hipster place

Bar Marco has been good in the past, but this time we went in for a No Menu Monday and I was disappointed with both the food and also the service.

I've gone here a couple of times before just for drinks and have been a big fan of both the drinks and also talking to the bartenders there. 

This time we came with a couple of friends from out of town and after coming in and being seated the server waited 5-10 minutes before informing us that it was No Menu Monday or asking us for our drink orders. Her attitude was also much more nonchalant with us than other customers and this really left a negative feel on the whole meal.  She gave us no suggestions even though our friends had never been there.

Food-wise they offered a Southern meal highlighting the chef from Gooski's. There was Pulled Pork, Collard Greens, Mac and Cheese and Corn on the Cob. The Pulled Pork and Mac and Cheese were good, but the Collard Greens and Corn on the Cob both seem to lack anything out of the ordinary.

I really want to say good things about Bar Marco based on past experiences, but based on what happened this occasion, I won't be back again.

This place is laughably pretentious.  The food is ok but not worth all the hype (top 33?? Really??!? C'mon pittsburgh!) or the money.  I had some roasted potatoes with mayonnaise with a way too fancy name that were decent, not anything you couldn't get at TGIFridays though, and a seriously salty plate of several strands of spaghetti, again with a fancier name and too high price.  

Don't even get me started on the bartenders and their "mental rolodexes" of drinks.  Anyone watch Portlandia?  This place is bad satire of a gastropub, except no one is in on the joke.  It's just sad.

Had the best brunch here! I got the soft scrambled eggs that had basil pesto in it and was served with a piece of buttered crusty bread. I tried several brunch cocktails on the menu and I was not disappointed at all! Their daily cheese changes with dishes and they will let you know what it is. Would highly advise you come here!
Kind of a weird place.  The layout is open but it feels too much like a cafe.  For breakfast/brunch we had pesto soft boiled eggs -- way too salty.  Price was a bit high, and generally was mediocre.

I went back & forth on what to rate Bar Marco and at the end of the day, it came down to the unique and fabulous experience that I had here. Chris made reservations for Valentine's day here and I couldn't have been more excited! I always wanted to come here but never really had a reason (PSA to all couples... it was also a super romantic Valentine's day spot). 

The atmosphere inside is very intimate and delightful. It is also super small- so I would definitely recommend trying to get reservations before going.  The minute I saw the interior, I knew this would be my kind of place! We were quickly greeted by our waiter (I wish I remembered his name). He was very attentive and provided spectacular service the whole night. I was so excited to order the bartender's choice drink & after describing to him what I was looking to drink- they delivered with a unique and delicious cocktail. This was probably my favorite part of the whole night!

The only downside of Bar Marco is the high price for the small portions that you receive for the food. We started with 2 appetizers, the arancini & cheese board. The arancini came with 2 servings and quickly became the best arancini that I have ever had. I would say this is a must to try here!  The cheese board was nothing special, it just had a few pieces of cheese and bread. For my meal, I decided on the bucatini carbonara, which was good, but not something I would order again & also a very small portion. Chris ordered the filet mignon that was melt in your mouth amazing- I wish I ordered that! 

Looking forward to coming back for more cocktails and brunch for my next visit!

Been here a handful of times for different occasions including group parties. The food is always delicious. You can eat from very light (quiches) to grubbing with their brunch burgers. the burger is what added another star to my review. the best! and their coffees are bound to put an extra pep to your step. The servers are a bit mundane but the perk to your meal is gratuity is included. A bit cramped indoors, very little seating area, but perhaps that is part of the experience. Not very toddler friendly, however they do have high chairs available.
Best burger I have ever had. Donuts were fantastic loved the lemon curd sauce. Service was great. Small place but very cozy. At the end of strip district so it's fun to walk to.

Calling all Foodies....  Bar Marco is a foodie's dream!  The service is impeccable...  Our waiter Alex knew the menu and was able to guide us to great selections from the snacks (appetizers), salad, and entree menu.  The stuffed dates are amazing as was the salad with grilled peaches and the quail.  We can't wait to go back!

Love it! Love the atmosphere. Love the cocktails. Love the locay. Love the service. What's not to love about this place? 

Translation: If you're on the Strip and looking for a classy place to pop in for a drink, you've just found it.

$5. $5. $5 Bar Marco! Every every every every... $5. $5. $5 Bar Marco!  Every every every...

Anyways.

We've been wanting to try Bar Marco's food for quite some time after stopping for drinks on multiple occasions...  fast forward, and Polar Vortex $5 happy hours, brunch, and a wine room excursion are all booked (brunch and wine room will be updated soon!).

Let me sum it up in short.  Normally, I feel Marco is a bit overpriced.  Is it good...?  yes.  Are the drinks worth $12 and the small bites for $10+...? no.  BUT, add in the Tuesday special, and this is one of the best deals in town.

$5 drinks (I recommend the Manhattan), $5 bar bites (if you don't get the burger you're crazy) and $5 other delicious goods (bacon wrapped dates, soup and arancini).  Do yourself a favor and grab a reservation just in case they're busy (it can fluctuate week to week).  Then drink, eat and repeat...  that simple.

While it's pricey, judging by our initial food experience, I'm excited to see what brunch holds and more importantly, the wine room!  Updates soon!

This place is way overrated.

I came here with my significant other for happy hour and the entire food menu was half off. And even at half off, some of the dishes were extremely overpriced. Yes, like everyone else says, the portions are tiny. This is what we tried:
-Pig Face Croquettes $13: The only dish we were impressed with. You get 3 golf-ball-sized pieces of fried goodness laying in a bed of aoili. 
-Butternut Squash Soup $10: Creamy and on the thicker side, which is a texture I like, but the flavor was bland. 
-Kale Salad $10: The dressing was very sour....it was like eating kale doused in lemon juice.
-Smoked Eggplant $10: This was weird....room temperature eggplant topped with a very salty sauce. I can't tell what the sauce tasted like.
